titleStmt.title: The true state and condition of the kingdom of Ireland, sent to the House of Commons from their committee there; whose names are signed thereto, viz. Robert Reynolds, Robert Goodwyn, both members of the said House. Also the true relation of the great victory the Protestants in that kingdom, lately had against the rebels there; sent in a letter by Sir Richard Greenvill, to the said committee, who hath since commended it to the House of Commons. Together with a letter from Sir John Chicester, of great consequence, to Sir John Clotworthy a member of the said House. All which are appointed by the House of Commons to be printed to prevent false copies; and for the true satisfaction of all His Majesties loving subjects. Ordered by the Commons, that these letters, and relation, be forthwith printed and published. Hen. Elsynge, Cler. Parl. D. Com.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 27 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 4 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: The true state and condition of the kingdom of Ireland, sent to the House of Commons from their committee there; whose names are signed thereto, viz. Robert Reynolds, Robert Goodwyn, both members of the said House. Also the true relation of the great victory the Protestants in that kingdom, lately had against the rebels there; sent in a letter by Sir Richard Greenvill, to the said committee, who hath since commended it to the House of Commons. Together with a letter from Sir John Chicester, of great consequence, to Sir John Clotworthy a member of the said House. All which are appointed by the House of Commons to be printed to prevent false copies; and for the true satisfaction of all His Majesties loving subjects. Ordered by the Commons, that these letters, and relation, be forthwith printed and published. Hen. Elsynge, Cler. Parl. D. Com.

Goodwin, Robert, ca. 1601-ca. 1681.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Ireland -- History -- Rebellion of 1641 -- Early works to 1800.

revisionDesc.change: 2008-01 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2010-12 John LattaText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: BY our four former addre≈ø≈øes of the 2 of November, 13 of December, 17 of January; and 2 of February, we gave you faithfull accompt of the ≈øtate of affairs here, as they then ≈øtood, and by our la≈øt Letter of the 2 of February, we informed you of the Commi≈ø≈øion ≈øent to the Lord Marque≈ø≈øe and others, to meet with the chiefe≈øt of the Rebels, and to hear, and receive in writing, what they could ≈øay or propound; before the coming over of this Commi≈ø≈øion, many ill Symptomes did appear, but now things are grown to an evident cleerne≈ø≈øe: For upon Munday la≈øt a Letter was read at the Board, from His Maje≈øty (without any Secretaries name ≈øub≈øcribed,) the effect whereof was to this purpo≈øe; That His Majesty took notice, that they, the Lords, Ju≈øtices, and Councell, without His con≈øent, or Privity, had admitted us to be pre≈øent at their debates, and did require them, not to ≈øuffer us to be pre≈øent with them any more, as formerly we had been; The Lords, Ju≈øtices, and Councell thereupon re≈øolved to do accordingly; And on Tue≈øday morning, ≈øent Sir Paul Davis to our lodging, to acquaint us both with the Letter, and the re≈øolution they had taken upon it; But becau≈øe the words of the Me≈ø≈øage were not full enough, as we conceived, We de≈øired their Lord≈øhips to expre≈ø≈øe them≈øelves cleerly, whither we ≈øhould be admitted, or not, For we were but ≈øervants to the Parliament, and mu≈øt give a ≈øtrict accompt of our Actions to tho≈øe which ≈øent us thither; Thereupon Sir Paul Davis returned to the Board, and acquainted their Lord≈øhips herewith, And after an hour came to us, with a ≈øecond Me≈ø≈øage, which we immediately put down in writing, (viz.) That the Lords, Ju≈øtices, and Councell, had formerly acquainted us, by him, with a Letter they had received from His Maje≈øty, That they were re≈øolved to obey His Maje≈øties commands; and therefore they could not admit us any more to be pre≈øent as a Committee.

Sir, you will ea≈øily imagine that affairs are ≈øteered here by the Court Compa≈ø≈øe; and if the de≈øign be to make peace with the Rebels, that ≈øo this Army may be applicable el≈øewhere: Our pre≈øence any longer at the Board, will not further that de≈øign; however, The time we have there ≈øpent, and the experience gained by that, will perhaps be ≈øerviceable to you at our return, which we now ha≈øten (as becomes us) all we can, And re≈øolve to depart hence this week, being retarded only to ≈øee the Lord Li≈øle in a good Po≈øture for his hopefull Expedition, be being re≈øolved to march on Tue≈øday next. We conceive it very nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øend a Ship of ≈øtrength and tru≈øt to ride in Bullock-Road before Dublyn, and another of le≈ø≈øe burthen, to ride before Drogheda.

Sir, We have to the utmo≈øt of our weak Abilities, indeavoured to wade through the dangers and difficulties, which on all ≈øides do attend our imployment here; but that which does exceedingly a≈øtoni≈øh us, is, That we have not been honoured with one Letter ≈øince our coming over.

We had almo≈øt forgot to tell you, That the labour is on both ≈øides the Sea, to make the Rebels appear ≈øtrong and con≈øiderable, and to put difficulties and impediments upon our Military proceedings, the better to bring on a mo≈øt horrid pernitious peace, which all goodmen here do abhorre, and are re≈øolved to abandon the Kingdom, rather then to be expo≈øed to an utter extirpation upon the next opportunity, which tho≈øe bloudy, but incon≈øiderable vi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ains can l ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ y ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ .

You may ≈øee their in-nate valour by our late victory over them upon Tue≈øday the ≈øeventh of February, an exact relation whereof made by Sir Richard Greenvell, who commanded in chief, we ≈øend you here inclo≈øed, and you may ≈øee their inveterate malice, who a week after this Commi≈ø≈øion came over, and the day appointed for to hear their Complaints, Did combine to make ≈ølaughter of a Convoy that pa≈ø≈øed by them, without offering them any violence, But were ≈øhamefully defeated of their expectation, and hath ≈øo di≈øheartned them, that we are confident, my Lord Li≈øle ≈øhall march where he plea≈øes, with his 2000 foot, and 300 hor≈øe; and what Religion, or to the Crown of England, do tho≈øe ≈øhew that advi≈øe His Maje≈øty, to a di≈øhonourable peace, which tho≈øe mi≈øcreants which will are long (if you do not exceedingly neglect this ≈øervice) disband, ≈øtarve, and cut-throats among them≈øelves.
Thus with our mo≈øt humble and hearty Prayers to the Almighty, for an honourable and ≈øpeedy Accommodation, we humbly take our leaves, and remain

closer.signed:
Your humble and faithfull Servants,
Robert Reynolds,
Robert Goodwyn.

div.head: A Relation concerning the Fight that happenned at RATHCONNELL.
div.p: BY command from the Lord Marque≈ø≈øe of Ormond, certain Forces of both Hor≈øe and Foot were ≈øent unto Trym, for the relief of Athlone, with a direction unto Sir Richard Greenvill to have the chief Command thereof; which Forces arrived at Trym on Thur≈øday 26 January; and on Friday morning then following, Sir Richard marched thence toward Athlone with about 900 Foot, and al≈øo about 200 Hor≈øe; and that night all lodged at Athboy.

Saturday the 28, being come nigh unto Ballinacur, being a very ≈øtrong pa≈ø≈øe, we found the Enemy po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing it with 300 men, having cut off there a Bridge, whereat Sir Richard commanded certain Dragooners to force that Pa≈ø≈øe, and al≈øo ≈øent a Party of Hor≈øe to ≈øecond them; which the enemy oppo≈øed, untill ≈øome of the Hor≈øe found a place there by, where they leapt over a deep ditch of water; which put them all to ≈ølight over a Bogge there by: In which e≈øcape divers of the Rebells were ≈ølain, and as it is ≈øaid, al≈øo one of their Commanders. That night we lodged at and about Killeenan.

Sunday the 29, marching forwards, 4 of our Hor≈øe Scouts e≈øpyed 4 Hor≈øe Scouts of the Rebells, on the top of a hill before them; who ≈øeeing our Scouts, ha≈øtning towards them, with≈øtood them, being Country Gentlemen of good quality; and being but 4 to 4, they encountred each other a while fairly, with onely their ≈øwords, untill one of the Rebells had both given and received a wound, and was ≈øeized on by one of our Scouts; whereat the re≈øt, being very well mounted, e≈øcaped away, leaving their confort to be ≈ølain in the place: And being come nigh Tobbercormick (where we lay that night) ≈øome of our Hor≈øe took a Gentlewoman of ≈øome quality pri≈øoner, who ≈øtood on a hill there by, guarded with ≈øome Muskettiers.

Munday the 30, being come within 5 miles of Athlone, we took one M. Richard Dillon pri≈øoner, who informed Sir Richard, That Generall Pre≈øton was ≈øending all
the Forces he could make, to hinder our coming to Athlone, and therefore wi≈øhed us to make all the ha≈øte thither we could: Pre≈øently thereon, a Hor≈øe-man of our forlorn hope came back, and informed Sir Richard, That ≈øeven Colours of the enemies Forces were then marching towards us. Sir Richard then pre≈øently commanded forth more of his Hor≈øe to ha≈øten to ≈øecond the fore-Troop, which in that Intrim charged the enemy, who retreated to a Bog, where mo≈øt of them might have been out off, had not the care of the Safe-Conduct of the provi≈øions appointed for the relief of Athlone forbidden it. That night we all came ≈øafe at Athlone, where we all ≈øtayed the next day following.

Wedne≈øday the 31, Sir Richard ≈øent all our Hor≈øe and Foot to quarter at Kilkenny-We≈øt, four miles thence, untill ≈øuch time as 300 of the Lord Rannelaugh's Regiment, and three hundred of Sir Michael Earnlyes Regiment could be drawn thither from their out-Garri≈øons, to march back with us: And when our Hor≈øe approached nigh unto Kilkenny, they di≈øcovered that it was ≈øtrongly manned by Sir James Dillons Forces, Captain Thomas his Troop, and Colonell Farrell's Regiment, of the County of Longford; whereat Captain Vaughan, with ≈øome of our Hor≈øe, fell into their Quarters, and killed a Captain, and ≈øome other Officers, and al≈øo about 50 of their Souldiers, and took many of their Arms, and po≈ø≈øe≈øt their Quarters untill Saturday.

Saturday the 4 of Febr: we all quartered at and about a place called, The Moat, at which time the 600 of the Lord Rannelaugh's, and Sir Michael Earnlyes Regiments were lodged with ours, where Captain Vaughan found in his Quarters an Engli≈øh mans wife, who told him, that the generall report of the Countrey was, That the Iri≈øh had gathered all the Forces they could get together, and were confident to compa≈ø≈øe us in on every ≈øide, and to cut us all off, re≈øolving and vowing not to leave a man of us alive: ≈øaying al≈øo, That if we ≈øhould get the Victory, the heart of their Wars would be broken, for that there was an ancient Prophe≈øie much talked of among the Iri≈øh, That that ≈øide which ≈øhould win the Battell at Rathconnell, ≈øhould be Conquerers of the Kingdom; it being a Tradition ≈øuper≈øtitiou≈øly held among≈øt the Native Iri≈øh.

On Munday the 5 and 6, we marched towards Trym, meeting with no oppo≈øition, but very foul weather and wayes, which greatly di≈øheartned the Souldiers, and killed divers of them; in which time we took ≈øeverall of the Countrey people, who all confirmed the former reports of the enemies Forces, and intentions: Sir Richard Greenvill notwith≈øtanding ≈øaid, He was re≈øolved not to march a foot out of his way, were the enemy never ≈øo ≈øtrong.

Tue≈øday the 7, proceeding in our March, we under≈øtood of divers Troops of Hor≈øe and Foot that daily had followed our Rear, which then was guarded by a Troop of Hor≈øe commanded by Lievtenant Hatcher, who charged certain Forces of the enemy which were advanced ≈øomewhat nigh him, and then cut off about twenty of them. Afterwards, about 11 of the clock the ≈øame day, being come nigh Mollingar, we took a pri≈øoner, who told us that the Iri≈øh Forces po≈ø≈øe≈øt our Pa≈ø≈øe of Rathconnell, a mile before us, being very ≈øtrong in number of men, and the prime Officers and Gentry of of the Countrey. Whereupon Sir Richard ha≈øtened the advance of his Forces towards the fore≈øaid Pa≈ø≈øe; and being come nigh in view of it, ≈øaw the Pa≈ø≈øe to be ≈øomewhat narrow, and that it was out off by a broad and deep Trench, being compa≈øt in on each ≈øide with great Boges, and having adjoyning to it on a very ≈øteep hill a ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle, and divers other Works well manned, by which there appeared no pa≈ø≈øage for
either Hor≈øe or Foot: Then did Sir Richard draw all his Forces into Battell-Order before it, which con≈øi≈øted of a forlorn hope of 50 Muskettiers, commanded by Lievtenant Dikes; and two Wings of ≈øixty ≈øhot more, commanded by two En≈øignes (one of them a coward) the forlorn hope being ≈øeconded with a Divi≈øion of 200 Muskettiers, which was commanded by Sir John Sherlecke, which was the Van-Guard of our little Army; whereof, the fir≈øt Divi≈øion was led by Captain Vern ‚Ä¢ y, and Lievtenant Oliver; and the ≈øecond Divi≈øion of it, by Lievtenant Williams; and al≈øo the third Divi≈øion by Major Morris. The re≈øt of the Forces con≈øi≈øted of three Divi≈øions of Pikes flanckt with ≈øhot, which were for the Battell of the Army, each containing about 300 men; whereof, the fir≈øt was led by Captain Honywood; the ≈øecond by Major Sir Abraham Shipman; the third by Sir Michael Earnely: after which followed another Divi≈øion of 200 Muskettiers, commanded by Major Fortelcue; which was for the Rear-Guard; who≈øe Rear was guarded by a forlorn hope of 50 Muskettiers, commanded by Likewi≈øe tho≈øe Foot were flanckt with three Divi≈øions of Hor≈øe; whereof Captain Vanghan commanded the Van-Guard; Lievtenant Rogers the Battell; and Lievtenant Hatcher the Rear-Guard. Likewi≈øe before the Van-Guard of the Feet, marched the Lord Rannelaugh, leading a Troop of Voluntiers. Likewi≈øe for the forlorn hope of the Rear Captain Pate commanded 40 Dragooners, which were al≈øo a≈ø≈øi≈øted with 20 Fire-locks: which done ≈øeeing not onely a ≈øtrong enemy of above 2000 Foot, and ≈øix Hor≈øe Troops before us, and others at lea≈øt 600 on our right hand, and 600 more of Longford men at a di≈øtance on our left hand, upon the Boggs, not farre off, from which were ha≈øtning up to ≈øecond their, as it is ≈øaid, 800 of the Realies; and then, unknown to us, there was waiting upon our Rear 500 more, which then newly po≈ø≈øe≈øt Mollingar, about half a mile behinde us, to hinder our Retreat. Then, for to begin the Play, the forlorn hope of 50 Shot, advanced on right towards the Pa≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo likewi≈øe did the left Wing of Shot, to ≈ølank that, the right Wing ≈øtaying behinde, contrary to command, who≈øe ground notwith≈øtanding was made good by others: Tho≈øe together being advanced as farre as they could, were ≈øeconded by ≈øeverall Divi≈øions drawn out of the Van-Guard; which al≈øo di≈øputing it with the enemy, without any apparent good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, Sir Richard was enforced before the front of the re≈øt of the Forces, to ≈øay, There was no other remedy now, but we mu≈øt re≈øolve to tarry it, or die, becau≈øe he ≈øaw great numbers of men approaching towards our right hand, and likewi≈øe as many towards our left hand; which if they ≈øhould come to joyn with tho≈øe before us, would be too ≈øtrong for us; therefore now of nece≈ø≈øity all mu≈øt u≈øe their be≈øt endeavours to force thorow the Pa≈ø≈øe upon the enemy, and by ≈øo doing of it re≈øolutely, there was no doubt of good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe: Whereunto all men ≈øeemed very willing, and ≈øo accordingly the three Divi≈øions of the Battell advanced cheerfully, with their Colours flying, to force their way, Sir Richard keeping upon re≈øerve 250 Muskettiers; which three la≈øt Divi≈øions being come at pu≈øh of Pike with the Rebells that defended that Pa≈ø≈øe; and Sir Michael Earnly e≈øpying the advance of the Longford men on our left hand, marched towards them, and then pre≈øently received a Charge by the Hor≈øe that Captain Brian commanded, which by our Shot was repul≈øed, and Brian him≈øelf ≈øhot dead; and that gave a ≈øtop to the Longford men. In the Interim of this Conflict, many of the Forces from off the Ca≈øtle were running ≈øpeedily to charge our right Wing of Shot; which Sir Richard repul≈øed, by ≈øending among≈øt them more Shot from out of his la≈øt re≈øerve: Which ≈øudden fury being ≈øtopt, and the ≈øervice continuing violent on all
≈øides for two hours time, with a doubtfull ≈øucce≈ø≈øe: Sir Richard ≈øent forth all the remainder of the Foot, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt tho≈øe at the Pa≈ø≈øe; during which Skirmi≈øh, Lievtenant Rogers did at ≈øeverall times very earne≈øtly de≈øire Sir Richard to give him leave to attempt to force a way thorow that Pa≈ø≈øe, with the Hor≈øe that he commanded; whereto at la≈øt Sir Richard gave him leave, and wi≈øht him good ≈øpeed; whereat he willingly departed, and ha≈øted to finde his way: And being come at the Banck and ditch of the Pa≈ø≈øe, found no po≈ø≈øible means there of getting thorow; whereat Major Morris called unto Lievtenant Rogers, ≈øaying, He had found a place for his Hor≈øe to pa≈ø≈øe thorow; then that Troop ha≈øted unto it, which Edward Ro≈øcarrocke of the ≈øaid Troop, fir≈øt rid thorow, the Lievtenant and the re≈øt of the Troop clo≈øely followed; and being gotten over, the forlorn hope Troop, led by Cornet Dixsay, followed them; and then pre≈øently did tho≈øe our Ho ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ≈øe charge the enemies Hor≈øe that were before them; who being not willing to receive them, began all to run away: in the pur≈øuit whereof, Lievtenant Rogers, with the Troop he commanded, chanced to follow a Troop, in who≈øe Rear was taken pri≈øoner Colonell Anthony Pre≈øton, the elde≈øt ≈øon of Generall Pre≈øton; and al≈øo there were ≈ølain many others of the ≈øaid Troop. At the ≈øame time Cornet Dix≈øay commanding the forlorn hope, pur≈øued another Hor≈øe Troop, killed many of them, and found the dead body of Captain Bryan, who was lately fled from Sir Thomas Lucas Troop; who≈øe head was there cut off, and brought away by Cornet Dix≈øey; our Foot having been at lea≈øt two hours before at handy blows, and throwing ≈øtones with the enemy, our men with one accord cheerfully came on upon tho≈øe that manned the Trenches, which made them al≈øo re≈øolutely run away: which ≈øudden change drew after them all the re≈øt of Our Forces: and being po≈ø≈øe≈øt of their works and hill, Sir Richard gave charge unto Sir John Sherlocke, That he with all convement ≈øpeed ≈øhould draw, and keep together his men in good order upon that ground, and furni≈øh all his men with Munition, while he him≈øelf, with the Hor≈øe, pur≈øued the Longford men flying away; and then pre≈øently did Sir Richard, Captain Vaughan, and Lievtenant Rogers, with about 40, or 50 Hor≈øe pur≈øue them, wherein it chanced, That Captain Vaughan, with a part of tho≈øe Hor≈øe, taking another way, was guided by Noble Sir Charles Coct that wayward that the enemy was e≈øcaped; and at la≈øt overtook the greate≈øt part of them, and there killed, as by them all is believed, at lea≈øt 200 of them; ≈øo that we verily believe, there were killed in all nigh 250: During which pur≈øuit, our Foot remaining about the enemies Ca≈øtle, ≈øearching, as they u≈øually do, all holes found in the Ca≈øtle 8 En≈øignes of the Rebells: and al≈øo Captain Betagh, Captain Dowdall, and Lievtenant Elmore, and three other of their En≈øigns, were found abroad among the dead bodies.

In this conflict of our men was killed in that place, but onely three ≈øouldiers, and about twenty Officers, and Souldiers hurt, whereof Serjeant Major Shipman, who then ≈øhewed him≈øelf a very valiant Souldier, was ≈øhot about two Inches deep, nigh the brea≈øt, and yet his Doublet not broken, Captain Verney ≈øhot on his brea≈øt, and yet not wounded, Captain Loftus had the Tip of his Ear a little hurt with a ≈øhot, Lievtenant Oliver ≈øhot in the brea≈øt, and not wounded, Lievtenant Moal ≈øhot in the forehead, and but ≈ølightly hurt, Lievtenant Bingham ≈øhot in the back, and his skin not hurt; which done, our forces marched thence, and lodged that night at Ma≈øi≈øtown, and in the field before the forces were drawn into their quarters, Sir Richard cau≈øed a Mini≈øter in the head of all the Troops, publikely to give God thanks (every man kneeling) for the victory, publikely ≈øaying, That it was the work onely of God, and
not of men, which every man ≈øeemed thankfully to acknowledge. This night we under≈øtood there was ≈ølain in the fight, Colonell Patrick, Plunckot, Captain Bryan, and Sir Thomas Nugents onely ≈øonne and heir, Captain John Nugent of Ballini≈øcarry, Captain Adam Cu≈øack a Parliament man, Captain Marcas Geoghagan, Captain Roger Darcy of Rattin.

Al≈øo the names of the Enemies Commanders, that were at the battle, are Serjeant Major Generall, James Preston, Colonell Anthony Pre≈øton, Colonell Mac Thomas Fitz-Gerald, Colonell Pe√Ørce Fitz-Gerald, Sir Luke Fitz-Gerald, Colonell Roger Moore, Colonell Terrell, Colonell Walter Nugent, Colonell Mulmore √¥ Realy, Colonell Brian Farrell. Sir Thomas Nugent, the Lord of Trimel≈øton.

Likewi≈øe the names of the ≈øuperiour Officers of our Army, are the≈øe, The Lord Vi≈øcount Rannelaugh, Sir Richard Greenvile, Colonell Sir Michael Earnely, Colonell Sir John Sherlock, Lievtenant Colonell Gibbs, Serjeant Major Sir Abraham Shipmaen, Serjeant Major A≈øhly, Serjeant Major Morris, Serjeant Major Forte≈øcue, Captain Honywood, Captain Lucas, Captain Verney, Captain Sands, Captain Loftus, Captain Nichols, Captain Palmer, Sir William Bronkett, Captain Vaughan, Captain Banger, Captain Gee, Lievtenant Oliver; Al≈øo for the Hor≈øe, Captain Vaughan, Lievtenant Hatcher, and for Dragooners, Captain Pate; All which Officers did excellently perform their ≈øervices, as did all the inferiour Officers, excepting onely En≈øign Lake.

That night Sir Richard Greenvile, in giving out his orders for the watch, gave out for that nights watch-word, the word (Revenge,) and al≈øo for the field, the word (Justice,) which was corre≈øpondent to Gods ble≈ø≈øing in the Victory.
Wedne≈øday the 8, we lodged at Ma≈øi≈øtowne.
Thur≈øday the 9, all forces quartered about Tryme, from whence they marched the next day into their former Garri≈øons.

We are at length come out if our mi≈øerable impri≈øonment, where the ≈øufferings of our Ears and Eyes, Did not a little adde to what we al≈øo felt, in a great proportion, by ≈øeeing and hearing the mi≈øerall Spectacles, and ≈øad cryes of our di≈øtre≈ø≈øed poor Souldiers, God be thanked, All that were left of us, are come hither in much ≈øafety, and by a cour≈øe much better, then if we had not incountred with ≈øuch difficulties: For when we were come a mile on this ≈øide Mullingar, at Reconnell, where the enemy had made him≈øelf very ≈øtrong in good works, They there being 6000 foot, and 10 or 12 Troops, kept the pa≈ø≈øage again≈øt our men, who≈øe number were not above a thou≈øand foot, be≈øides my Lord Pre≈øidents men, be brought from Connaught with them, and who≈øe good fortune it was to have the Van, and give the defeat: Herein Colonell Greenvill hath behaved him≈øelf very well; We have killed of the enemy 500 on the place, among≈øt whom, is the great Commander Plunker, and another Colonell; We have taken Pre≈øtons Sonne (who was al≈øo a Colonell) Pri≈øoner, and Bryan, that was ≈øent from you hither, and proved Appo≈øtate hath lo≈øt his head in the skirmi≈øh. We have many Captains, and other inferiour Officers, Pri≈øoners; al≈øo have brought home nine En≈øignes. If it is be pro≈øecuted effectually, as I hope it will, The power and courage of that Rebellious breed, mu≈øt be exceedingly le≈ø≈øened.

But alas Brother, our extremities for want of victuall is beyond Imagination, And if pre≈øent
remedy be not provided effectually, all the Officers will over to the King, quit the Kingdom, and the whole De≈øign mu≈øt be lo≈øt: Now we are through the concurrance of mo≈øt evident manife≈øtations of Gods goodne≈ø≈øe in a probable way of reducing the≈øe mi≈ø-creants for ever; but if we are lo≈øt, as we mu≈øt be by pretermitting this pre≈øent ≈øupply, ten times over the expence If both bloud and Trea≈øure, which will now in appearance fini≈øh the work, will not then put us in the State we are now po≈ø≈øe≈øt off. You cannot imagine to what heights all ≈øorts of people are come unto, being made de≈øperate by the ≈øufferings they have undergone, and little hopes of being relieved, as bad as things goe. My Lord Li≈øle, with Colonell Monck, and Cromwell, having 1500 foot, and 300 hor≈øe, ≈øome great and field Peeces, Bend their cour≈øe towards Athy, which will induce Pre≈øton either to fight with them, or quit Kilkenny. At the ≈øame time my Lord More and Titchbourn, intend to go forth with all their forces to Ea≈øt and We≈øt Meath, and Cavan; God ≈øend us his countenance and favour, whil≈øt we are in ≈øuch neglects from man.

The King hath ≈øent expre≈ø≈øe order, That your hone≈øt Committees ≈øhall not be admitted to the Coun≈øell Table, as formerly; and I fear they intend to go hence immediately, God knows what inconveniency will ari≈øe by their coming away; though I mu≈øt confe≈ø≈øe, They have but poor incouragement to ≈øtay. We bear you have had good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe lately in Killultagh, and at Enneskellen; but withall, That your want of Victuall, is like to put a ≈øoon end unto all controver≈øies, I am ≈øure you hear from thence more particularly then we can.

When you repre≈øent your own nece≈ø≈øities, fail not to remember ours, and God put you into the Po≈øture, to mini≈øter help unto us, otherwi≈øe, let's know immediately, That we may not dye in a ditch, and ≈øtarve, which is the condition, threatning us all. I ≈øhall be more particular in my next, if God continue us a being; but now can adde no more, onely my mo≈øt humble Service to my deer Si≈øter, and that I am

closer.signed: Your faithfull Servant, and affectionate Brother John Chice≈øter.

postscript.p: I forgot to tell you, that Captain Vaughan, who brought this news, was Knighted by the Ju≈øtices, upon the report of it; And that my Lord hath left ≈øufficient ≈øtrength in the Ca≈øtles of Athlone Ro≈øconian, and the Boil of the old Souldiers, who ≈øo long as their victuall can la≈øt, will certainly give a good accompt of tho≈øe ≈øtrengths.

div.trailer: For Sir John Clotworthy Knight, in Ca≈øtle-yard, in Holborne.
